Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Situation2: They prepare a sermon for Sunday service to guide the congregation in moral decisions.
Story: I sat at my desk, the thick manila folder from the courthouse staring at me, its contents waiting to be dissected. As a judge, I was expected to review every detail, no matter how routine the case seemed. The hearing was in two weeks, but I knew the importance of being prepared—justice demanded diligence. Yet, on the other side of my desk, my Bible lay open, notes for Sunday’s sermon scattered around it. My congregation looked to me for guidance, for words that would help them navigate the moral complexities of their lives. I was supposed to teach them about forgiveness and compassion, to help them see the world through the lens of faith. But as I tried to focus on the legal documents, my mind kept drifting to the sermon, to the responsibility I felt for the souls in my care. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my full attention, each expecting me to be wholly present. I felt torn, caught between the law and the spirit, unsure which duty to serve first.
